speaker: RESIDENT
text: Hi Ms. ___. I’m one of the medicine residents. You came in from the dialysis unit after feeling faint, short of breath, and sweaty while you were on your way to see your kidney doctor. Can you tell me in your own words what happened today and over the last week or so?

speaker: PATIENT
text: I was walking to my appointment and in the lobby I suddenly felt really short of breath, lightheaded, and cold and sweaty. It’s been happening a lot. This past week I get short of breath just walking to the bathroom. I almost passed out in the shower last week. No chest pain, just feel like I might faint.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Thank you. In the emergency room your blood pressure was low but you were thinking clearly and your oxygen level was good on room air. They gave you an IV antibiotic dose and drew blood cultures, and your chest X-ray didn’t show any pneumonia or fluid in the lungs. Your EKG showed a normal rhythm. Does that match what you were told?

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yeah, they said my pressure was low but that happens with dialysis. They did an X-ray and heart test and said they looked okay. I don’t remember all the details.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: You also mentioned some other symptoms—left-sided headaches you’ve been treating with Tylenol and Percocet, some nausea with a couple of episodes of vomiting a few nights ago, and right knee and thigh pain that’s been getting worse over weeks. Is that still going on now?

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yes, the headache on the left is pretty constant, kind of achy. I’ve been taking Tylenol and Percocet around the clock. I had nausea and threw up twice a few nights ago but not today. My right leg still aches, especially the knee and thigh.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: I see. I also see in your chart that you have HIV and are on your medications, you’re on hemodialysis three times a week through the catheter in your left chest, and you’ve had trigeminal neuralgia or shingles on the right side of your face with chronic pain and eye involvement. You also have a history of atrial fibrillation and peripheral neuropathy. Is that all correct?

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yes, I have HIV and I go to clinic for that. I’m on dialysis Monday, Wednesday, Friday. The right side of my face and eye have hurt since I had shingles there. And they told me I had an irregular heartbeat before. My feet and legs tingle a lot too.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: On exam right now your blood pressure is about 98 over 60, your heart rate is around 100, you’re breathing comfortably with good oxygen, and your lungs sound mostly clear with just faint crackles at the bases. Your heart sounds regular, your belly is soft and not tender, and your neurologic exam is normal. You do look a bit dry in the mouth. We’ll admit you to the medicine floor, keep you on the monitor, and check more labs to look for causes of the low blood pressure and shortness of breath.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I just don’t want to pass out again. Will you figure out why my pressure keeps dropping?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: That’s our goal. We’re thinking about volume shifts from dialysis, possible adrenal gland problems, heart rhythm issues, or infection. We’ll keep you on telemetry, get an echocardiogram of your heart, and do blood tests including cortisol and repeat chemistries. We’ll also hold your diltiazem for now since it can lower blood pressure.

speaker: NURSE
text: Ms. ___, I’m your nurse on the floor. Your vitals right now are stable—temperature 97.7, blood pressure 98 over 60, heart rate 100, breathing 18, oxygen 98% on room air. I’m going to start your scheduled medications, including your HIV meds, dialysis-related meds, and eye ointment, and I’ll draw some morning labs a bit earlier because the team wants to check your calcium and kidney numbers.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Alright. I’m okay with the meds. My head still hurts on the left though. Can I get something for that?

speaker: NURSE
text: You have acetaminophen ordered as needed and also oxycodone if the pain is more severe. I’ll bring you some Tylenol first and see if that helps, and I’ll let the team know your headache is still pretty bad.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Good morning, Ms. ___. I’m the attending physician. I’ve reviewed your labs from early this morning. Your calcium level is quite high at 12.7, your phosphate is 5.1, and your kidney numbers are elevated as expected with your end-stage renal disease. Your blood counts show a normal hemoglobin and platelets, with slightly large red blood cells. We think the high calcium may be contributing to your fatigue, nausea, and possibly your low blood pressure.

speaker: PATIENT
text: High calcium? I didn’t know that could make me feel this tired and sick. Is that from my kidneys?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: In people on dialysis, high calcium can be related to overactive parathyroid glands, adrenal issues, or, less commonly, cancers. Your parathyroid hormone level is elevated at 286, which fits with long-standing kidney disease, and your alkaline phosphatase is normal, which is somewhat reassuring. We’ll also check vitamin D and a parathyroid hormone–related protein, and we’ll use dialysis to help bring the calcium down. We’re continuing your cinacalcet to help control the parathyroid overactivity.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. As long as it comes down. I’ve also been really nauseated sometimes. Is that from the calcium too?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: It could be. Hypercalcemia often causes nausea and vomiting. We’re giving you anti-nausea medicine like ondansetron as needed, and we’ll also get liver tests and an ultrasound of your abdomen to make sure there’s no gallbladder or liver problem contributing. So far your liver enzymes and bilirubin are normal.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That sounds good. My stomach feels okay right now, just a little queasy sometimes.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’re also concerned about your presyncope and low blood pressure. We’ll keep you on the heart monitor for now. Your echocardiogram is ordered to look at your heart function and valves. We’ll also do a cortisol stimulation test tomorrow to see if your adrenal glands are working properly.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Alright. I just want to know why I keep almost passing out. I’m scared it’ll happen at home again.

speaker: NURSE
text: Ms. ___, radiology is ready for your head CT because of your headaches. We’ll take you down now. It’s a quick scan and doesn’t use contrast.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. My head has been really bothering me, so I hope it shows what’s going on.

speaker: CONSULT
text: Ms. ___, I’m from the radiology team. Your head CT shows no bleeding, no mass, and no stroke. There are some heavy calcifications along the membranes in your brain, which we often see in people with long-standing kidney disease, but nothing acute or dangerous.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So no tumor or bleeding? That’s a relief. But why does my head still hurt?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’re glad the CT is normal. Your headaches could be from migraine, tension, neuropathic pain, or even related to your HIV medications. We briefly tried carbamazepine this morning for possible trigeminal neuralgia, but we stopped it the same day. For now we’ll continue to treat your pain with oxycodone as needed and reassess as an outpatient for migraine-specific medications if needed.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Alright. The pain meds help some. I’ll talk to my regular doctor about other options later.

speaker: NURSE
text: Your evening labs just came back. Your calcium is still high at 11.7, and your ionized calcium is 1.45, which is elevated. Your pH is normal. The team plans to use your dialysis session tomorrow to help bring the calcium down further.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So it’s still high. I hope dialysis helps. I usually feel wiped out after dialysis though.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Good morning. Your labs this morning show your calcium has come down a bit to 12.0, creatinine is 10.0, BUN 62, and your electrolytes are otherwise stable. Your blood counts are acceptable, with hemoglobin 13.2 and platelets 179. We’ll proceed with dialysis today and avoid taking off fluid to prevent your blood pressure from dropping.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Thank you. I always feel like they take too much fluid off and that’s when I get dizzy. So no fluid off today?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Correct. Today’s dialysis will focus on clearing toxins and lowering your calcium, but we’ll avoid ultrafiltration. That should help keep your blood pressure more stable. We’ll also continue your cinacalcet and sevelamer, and we’ve started you on Nephrocaps for vitamins related to dialysis.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I’ll let you know if I feel lightheaded during dialysis.

speaker: CONSULT
text: Hi, I’m from nephrology. We’re managing your dialysis. Given your history of low blood pressure with treatments, we’ll run you today without removing fluid. We’ll also keep you on your usual Monday-Wednesday-Friday schedule and continue cinacalcet and sevelamer. Your phosphorus is mildly elevated but acceptable.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That sounds good. I really don’t like feeling like I’m going to pass out during dialysis.

speaker: NURSE
text: We’re taking you down for your dialysis session now. Your blood pressure is in the 90s over 60s, heart rate in the 90s, and you’re afebrile. The dialysis orders specify no fluid removal today.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay, I’m ready. I’m a little nervous but I’m glad they’re not pulling fluid.

speaker: CONSULT
text: Dialysis went smoothly. We didn’t remove any fluid, and your blood pressure stayed in your usual low range without you feeling faint. This should also help bring your calcium down further.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I feel tired but not as bad as usual. I didn’t get that same dizzy feeling this time.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We also did your echocardiogram. It shows normal heart pumping function, normal chamber sizes, and no significant valve problems or pericardial effusion. There’s no structural heart reason for you to be passing out.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So my heart is okay. That’s good to hear. Then it’s more from the dialysis and maybe the calcium?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Exactly. We think your presyncope is most likely from fluid shifts with dialysis and possibly medication effects, rather than a heart structural problem. We’ve stopped your diltiazem, and tomorrow we’ll start a medication called midodrine to help support your blood pressure.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I was on that diltiazem for my heart rhythm, right? It’s okay to stop it?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Yes. You have a history of atrial fibrillation, but during this stay you’ve been in normal sinus rhythm on the monitor. Given your low blood pressure, we think the risks of diltiazem outweigh the benefits right now, so we’re stopping it. If your rhythm issues recur, we’ll reassess with your outpatient doctors.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Alright. As long as you’re watching my heart while I’m here.

speaker: NURSE
text: Your afternoon labs after dialysis show your calcium has improved to 10.0, your creatinine is down to 4.7, BUN 22, and your potassium is 3.9. Your white count is a bit low at 3.6, and your red cells are still a little large, which is similar to your prior labs.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So the calcium is better now. I do feel a bit less wiped out. My headache is still there but not as bad.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: That’s encouraging. We also drew cortisol levels at different times today and gave you a dose of cosyntropin to test your adrenal glands. Your cortisol levels, including after stimulation, show an appropriate rise, which means you do not have adrenal insufficiency.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So my adrenal glands are okay too. That’s good. I’m glad you’re figuring this out.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We also sent blood cultures from your arm and from your dialysis line. So far, the one that’s resulted shows no growth, and the others are still pending. You’ve remained afebrile and your white count is low-normal, so infection seems unlikely as the cause of your symptoms.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I was worried about infection because of my HIV and the dialysis line. I’m glad nothing is growing so far.

speaker: NURSE
text: Good morning. Your labs today show calcium 11.2, creatinine 7.0, BUN 45, potassium 5.0, and your blood counts are stable with hemoglobin 12.8 and platelets 166. Your white count is slightly low at 3.8, similar to before. The team is talking about sending you home later today if things stay stable.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Going home sounds nice. I do feel better than when I came in. Still a bit tired, but not as short of breath.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We also completed your abdominal ultrasound. It shows no liver lesions, no bile duct blockage, and a normal gallbladder. There are many cysts in both kidneys, which we often see in people on long-term dialysis, and a small likely benign lesion in the spleen. No acute abdominal problem was found.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So my liver and gallbladder are okay. That’s good. I was worried the nausea meant something was wrong there.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’re planning for discharge later today. To summarize: your low blood pressure and presyncope are most likely from dialysis-related fluid shifts and medications. Your heart structure is normal, your adrenal testing is normal, and your calcium, while still a bit high, has improved with dialysis. Your nausea has improved, and your headaches are better controlled. We’ll stop your diltiazem, start midodrine 5 mg once daily to help with low blood pressure, continue your HIV regimen and dialysis-related meds, and give you prochlorperazine and oxycodone as needed for nausea and pain. We’ll also arrange outpatient testing of your leg arteries (ABIs) for your right leg pain.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Thank you for explaining. I’ll stop the diltiazem and take the new blood pressure pill. I’ll also follow up about my leg and headaches. I’m glad my heart and scans were okay.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Before you go, let’s review your discharge medications. Continue your HIV meds—atazanavir, lamivudine, ritonavir, and tenofovir weekly—as well as Bactrim on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. Continue cinacalcet, sevelamer with meals and snacks, aspirin, valacyclovir, folic acid, Nephrocaps, docusate, and your eye ointment. New or changed: stop diltiazem and Percocet; start midodrine 5 mg daily, prochlorperazine 10 mg every 8 hours as needed for nausea, and oxycodone 5 mg every 6 hours as needed for pain. We’ll send you home today; you’re afebrile, your systolic blood pressure is in the 90–100 range, and you’re walking independently.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That’s a lot, but I’ll follow the list you give me. I’m feeling better and ready to go home. Thank you all for taking care of me.
